channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Supreme Court to hear school disability discrimination case
item.description: At issue is a case testing the reach of federal laws that promise special help for children with disabilities in public schools. Specifically: What do parents have to prove in order to get that specialized help?

item.title: NATO chief calls for more defense spending from Europe and Canada
item.description: President Trump has long been a critic of NATO and believes Europe does not contribute enough to its own defense. NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte agrees, and says 'that is going to happen.'

item.title: Financial stress can damage your mental health. These steps may help
item.description: With people losing their jobs and the stock market rocky, there's a lot of financial anxiety right now. Research shows how you approach it can be key to protecting your mental and physical health.

item.title: Canada's election: All you need to know
item.description: Canada's snap election has been dominated by one politician — who's not even in the race: President Trump.

item.title: Violinist Esther Abrami uncovers 'hidden treasure' of music by women
item.description: French violinist and social media influencer Esther Abrami releases her new album, Women, featuring music by female composers in a bid to redress historic biases.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Federal authorities arrested more than 100 immigrants without legal status in Colorado Springs, Canadians go to the polls today, how West Texas is fairing three months into the measles outbreak.

item.title: Wisconsin judge arrested by FBI 'stood up' for her community, state lawmaker says
item.description: The FBI's arrest of Wisconsin Judge Hannah Dugan is meant to scare officials and others from "standing up to the Trump regime," says Democrat State Rep. Ryan Clancy.

item.title: What happens when the federal government stops funding university research
item.description: The federal government has cancelled about 11 billion dollars worth of university research funding, and is threatening to cut more. When the federal government stops funding research, there's no one else to take on those costs.

item.title: A man drove a car into a crowd in Vancouver Saturday night, killing at least 11
item.description: Eleven people were killed and more than two dozen injured after a man drove an SUV into a crowd of people at a Filipino festival on Saturday in Vancouver, British Columbia.

item.title: How West Texas is faring, three months into the measles outbreak
item.description: The measles outbreak is not easing up around the country. The CDC reports 884 confirmed cases nationwide, three times the number of cases in 2024. In West Texas, where the outbreak started, pediatricians are concerned about potentially more children being exposed to the virus.
